Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will support research activity at Thomas Jefferson National Laboratory in Newport News, VA. The PI plays a significant role in a major new experiment known as GlueX (presently under construction, with data taking expected within three or four years), whose focus is the study of meson spectra. The theory of the strong interaction, quantum chromodynamics (QCD), predicts not only the existence of mesons that have been observed over decades of experiments, but also exotic states that are made up of quarks, anti quarks and gluons, as well as glueballs - states made up entirely of gluons. GlueX is specifically designed to help search for such states. The PI has primary responsibility for specific hardware: diamond radiators, photon tagger microscope, and photon collimator, all of which are essential for achieving the full scientific potential of the experiment.

The existence of so-called exotics and glueballs is a widely expected consequence of QCD, but as with any theory, confirmation is an essential component in our understanding even of non-exotic matter. Graduate student participation is an important part of the activity, both for the success of the project and for training of future scientific leaders. The hardware development has also engendered important ties with local companies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the most important scientific challenges in the field of Nuclear Physics today is to understand the how nuclei (ie. protons and neutrons) are built up from the elementary particles of nuclear matter which are quarks and gluons. To answer this challenge, a high-energy electron accelerator has been built called CEBAF (continuous electron beam accelerator facility) at the site of Jefferson Lab in Newport News, Virginia. One of the most direct ways to attack this problem is to inject a large amount of energy into a small region of the nucleus so that it is absorbed on just one or two quarks, and study the spectrum of excited states that emerges from the collision. According to the principle of confinement (see Fig. 1) no matter how much energy is injected it is not possible to rip a quark out of its host particle, but it should be possible to pump large amounts of energy into the gluonic bond between the quarks. The “gluonic excitations” GlueX experiment has been built at Jefferson Laboratory in an attempt to create this effect using a beam of high-energy photons (gamma rays) incident on a target of liquid hydrogen (see Fig. 2).

The GlueX experiment is undertaken by a collaboration of over 100 scientists and engineers at a number of unversities, in addition to  Jefferson Lab. The University of Connecticut (UConn) is an active participant in this effort. With support from the National Science Foundation and other funding sources, UConn reseachers have taken responsibility for a several key components for the GlueX expeirment, including producing the diamond wafers for the photon source, and construction of the “tagging” detectors that are used to determine the energy of the photon beam. Fig. 3 illustrates the laser technology that the UConn team uses to take a single-crystal diamond plate 0.25 mm thick and mill a central window out of it that is thin enough that it can be placed in the electron beam without excessive scattering. Because of the way that photons are produced in the crystal wafer, energies up to the maximum energy of the CEBAF accelerator, are present in the photon beam, so the individual energy of each one (millions per second) need to be measured using a fast timing technique called “tagging”. The UConn group has constructed a finely segmented detector for this purpose called the “tagger microscope” which uses optical fibers connected to tiny scintillators to detect the electrons and measure their energy and time of passage with high precision. The importance of the time measurement for tagging is explained in Fig. 4 and its caption.

As a public university, UConn is committed to serving the needs of the State of Connecticut and the nation by training the next generation of scientists and engineers in accelerator-based science. Nuclear physicists have built up a broad store of knowledge, both in theory and experimental craft, which is of high value and is best preserved by hands-on training like what happens when high school and college students work side-by-side with seasoned researchers on cutting-edge research. Fig. 5 shows a photograph of the UConn group during a weekly research group meeting in our laboratory area in the Physics Building at the UConn Storrs campus.  This photo was taken at the height of GlueX construction activity in summer 2013, and shows the broad impact that federal support of science at the universities has at the international, national, state and local level.
